title: New Data Shows Connecticut Among Worst States for Winter Road Conditions - NewsBreak
text:
By Ethan Carey ,
3 hours ago Natilyn Hicks What We K now About Connecticut’s Roads
According to a recent report from ctpublic.org , Connecticut ranks as the 5th worst state in the U.S. for overall road conditions, based on poor-road metrics from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA)’s Highway Performance Monitoring System. The same report notes that more than 2,100 miles of Connecticut roads are classified as in poor condition — and that “harsh winter weather exacerbates pavement deterioration.”
Download the WRKI Mobile App Now Why Bridges and Overpasses Freeze First
Experts point out that bridges and overpasses are the biggest troublemakers, freezing long before the roadways around them. It’s like they’re trying to win a contest none of us asked them to enter. Add in the cracks, potholes, and uneven pavement that winter tends to exaggerate, and you get conditions that change faster than your mood when someone drives 40 in the passing lane.
Read More: Unlocking Winter’s Secrets: How Will Winter 2026 Look In Danbury
The First Storm: A Not-So-Gentle Reminder
During the season’s first significant snowfall, Connecticut saw multiple spinouts and a few serious crashes — a reminder that winter weather doesn’t need to be dramatic to be dangerous. Black ice remains the silent villain, especially on backroads, shaded areas, and the winding hills that make Fairfield and Litchfield County so… “scenic.”
The “Highlight Reel” of Winter Driving Fails This year’s first legit storm already gave us the highlight reel: spinouts, rollovers, vehicles doing interpretive dance on I-84. One poor tractor-trailer ended up sideways like it was trying to parallel park across three lanes.
Read More : Will Pumping the Gas Pedal Heat Up Your Car Faster During CT Winters
Road Crews Do Their Best — But Nature Doesn’t Care
Road crews, to their credit, are out early and often, but even the best plow team can’t keep up with sudden refreezing overnight. That’s why officials recommend slowing down, braking gently, and leaving extra space between vehicles. Yes, even if you swear your SUV “handles great in snow.”
The Bottom Line: Respect the Season Winter driving in Connecticut isn’t about panic — it’s about respect. Respect for the weather, respect for the roads, and respect for the fact that the guy in front of you might not have cleared his roof off. Stay alert, stay patient, and most importantly, stay on all four wheels.
6 Restaurants Ideal for Winter Dining in Connecticut Google Street View Fife 'n Drum Restaurant - 53 Main Street, Kent, CT The Fife 'n Drum is one of our favorite restaurants in Connecticut because of its warm and inviting atmosphere, excellent food, and the talented musicians who play the piano on Friday and Saturday evenings.
House specialties are prepared tableside and include Caesar Salad for Two, Filet Mignon au Poivre, and Roast Half Duck Flambé and t hey offer vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free options on all of their menus. All menu items are available for takeout. Google Review rated excellent at 4.4/5. Getty Images Marygold's On Main - 19 Main Street, Newtown, CT Marygold's On Main is a must-visit for brunch, featuring their legendary cornflake French toast, which is truly exceptional. The food and craft cocktails are consistently excellent, and they also offer a great variety of mocktails to choose from.
Mindy and I visited this cozy restaurant soon after it opened and found the menu creative and delicious. The atmosphere is both beautiful and relaxing and a perfect backdrop for a romantic evening or a get-together with friends. Google Review Rating - 4.4/5. Google Street View John's Cafe - 693 Main Street South, Woodbury, CT John's Cafe is an intimate, cozy bistro with customers who consistently comment on the superb food, friendly staff, and creative menu. Mario's 5-star review of John's Cafe on Google kinda says it all: "I have been eating here every few months for at least 15 years as have my parents and many friends -- the food is consistently excellent and the wine list is noteworthy in terms of by the glass selections! The restaurant is very small and casual, but high-end in terms of its food and wines. The dishes are creative and consistently well done -- this is the type of place where you are never afraid to try something new or eclectic from the specials as the chef is top notch. John's Cafe is a little known gem with a consistent reputation and regular customers from all over the area." Getty Images The Griswold Inn - 36 Main Street, Essex, CT The Griswold Inn is not only immersed in Connecticut's rich history, which you can read about by clicking this link , but it also meshes perfectly with the cozy historic atmosphere and the good old-fashioned comfort food. Great shops and boutiques are within walking distance to enjoy a stroll before or after your meal.
Trip Advisor Review From 'dustythou***: "This restaurant deserves its fantastic reputation. It's the oldest continuously-running inn in the country, and the historic atmosphere only adds to the charm but doesn't detract from the delicious, contemporary menu. It was a good thing we had made a reservation, because this place was super busy! We were seated right away at a table tucked away from the hustle and bustle, and we shared a wonderful meal. Our waitress was super friendly and made sure we had everything we needed. " Google Street View Materia Ristorante - 637 Bantam Road, Bantam, CT Materia Ristorante is a fine-dining Italian restaurant that offers seasonal Italian cuisine, a selection of distinctive wines, and exceptional European hospitality in an inviting dining room. According to CT Magazine's list of top restaurants for 2025, Materia Ristorante has been recognized as one of the best dining establishments in Connecticut.
Materia Ristorante earns a 4.7/5 rating on Google Reviews. Here's why you might want to visit this charming restaurant according to a 5-star Google review from Mike C.... "What a phenomenal experience. Chef tasting menu was out of this world, unique, perfect. Wait staff was amazing. They had a great balance of checking in and keeping their distance. The restaurant was full but did not feel crowded at all. I highly recommend for anyone who wants a fine dining experience." Google Street View G.W. Tavern - 20 Bee Brook Road, Washington Depot, CT The G.W. Tavern in beautiful Washington Depot is named after the first U.S. president and offers a cozy dining experience in a charming colonial setting. The menu blends traditional and contemporary cuisines, highlighting local crops and seafood. G.W. Tavern is ideal for a romantic dinner or a special occasion.
Google Review - 4.5/5...Check out John M's 5-star review: "Once again, the GW Tavern was warm and cozy on a cold winter day. We had the mussels, French onion soup, and a sandwich, all delicious. The fire was warm and inviting with George Washington’s portrait hung over the hearth. Made me think of all the colonists who brought us this above wonderful country. Carry on GW Tavern, we’ll be back."
Three Locally-Made Hot Drinks Make Winter In Connecticut Bearable Are you obsessed with hot chocolate? Live for Hot Toddies? Warm apple cider? I love hot drinks when it's below freezing in Connecticut. Here are three of my favorite hot drinks, all locally-made, that my wife and I have been loving this Winter. Gallery Credit: Large Dave/Google Google Hot Chocolate at Kimberly Farm - New Milford At the suggestion of State Representative Bill Buckbee, Mrs. Large and I stopped at New Milford's Kimberly Farm and got ourselves two cups of their hot chocolate. Oh my God. Watch out Arethusa, your cows may have been way more expensive, but the milk at Kimberly Farm is superior. Mrs. Large Butter Me Up - Quin Brew Coffee Company- Watertown We stopped into Watertown's new Quin Brew Coffee Company at 1175 Main Street over the weekend, and got one of their January drink specials Butter Me Up. It's got homemade butterscotch, bourbon-flavored latte, and a butterscotch drizzle. It's outstanding. Mrs. Large Quin Brew - 1175 Main Street - Watertown Remember the Subway next to Enterprise? Right Across from Shaker's and Dunkin'? Stop in, it's a great place. Mrs. Large French Toast Latte - The Po - Washington Depot The Po Cafe in Washington is where you can a special Winter drink called French Toast Latte. It's espresso, local maple syrup, vanilla, nd cinnamon-infused milk, try it, and you'll see why most of our Christmas money has gone to the Po this Winter.
